name: Boom
headline: Economically and environmentally sustainable supersonic travel
description:
Boom Supersonic is transforming air travel with Overture, the world’s fastest airliner, optimized for speed, safety, and sustainability. Serving both civil and government markets, Overture will fly at twice the speed of today’s airliners and is designed to run on 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). Symphony™, a Boom-led collaboration with industry leaders, is the propulsion system that will power Overture. Overture’s order book, including purchases and options from American Airlines, United Airlines, and Japan Airlines stands at 130 aircraft. Boom is working with Northrop Grumman for government and defense applications of Overture. Suppliers and partners collaborating with Boom on the Overture program include Collins Aerospace, Eaton, Florida Turbine Technologies (FTT), a business unit of Kratos Defense & Security Solutions, Inc., GE Additive, Safran Landing Systems, StandardAero and the United States Air Force. For more information, visit https://boomsupersonic.com

Boom’s world-class engineering team comes from places including SpaceX, Boeing, Gulfstream, Virgin Galactic, Scaled Composites, NASA, and Bombardier. 

We have uniquely challenging and world-changing opportunities for the most talented aerospace engineers, designers, and business people.

# Boom Is Supersonic
The first civil supersonic jet made in America breaks the sound barrier.
[Learn More](https://boomsupersonic.com/</xb-1>)
![](https://boomsupersonic.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/home-xb-1-ssf2.jpg)
## XB-1
Supersonic Demonstrator
The XB-1 program has built the foundation for Boom to deliver supersonic travel, onboard Overture.
[Learn More](https://boomsupersonic.com/</xb-1>)
![](https://boomsupersonic.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/home-overture-edit.jpg)
## Overture
Supersonic Airliner
Overture will get you to global destinations two times faster—with orders from United Airlines, American Airlines, and Japan Airlines.
[Learn More](https://boomsupersonic.com/</overture>)
![](https://boomsupersonic.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/home-2024-symphony.jpg)
## Symphony™
Supersonic Engine
Turbofan engine purpose-built by Boom and optimized for supersonic flight.
[Learn More](https://boomsupersonic.com/</symphony>)
![](https://boomsupersonic.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/home-2024-superfactory.jpg)
## Superfactory
U.S. Manufacturing Facility
The first American supersonic airliner factory, located in Greensboro, North Carolina.
[Learn More](https://boomsupersonic.com/</superfactory>)
# Building The Supersonic Future
Boom is building the end-to-end value chain to bring commercial supersonic travel to the world.

generated_description:
Boom Supersonic is on a mission to revolutionize air travel with economically and environmentally sustainable supersonic jet technology. Founded in 2014 and hailing from Centennial, Colorado, Boom is building Overture, the world's fastest airliner. What sets Overture apart? It's designed to fly at twice the speed of current commercial planes while operating on 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). 

The propulsion system powering Overture, known as Symphony™, is a collaborative effort with industry leaders and is tailored specifically for supersonic travel. Currently, the company boasts an impressive order book of 130 aircraft from major airlines like American Airlines, United Airlines, and Japan Airlines. Beyond civil markets, Boom is also collaborating with Northrop Grumman for defense applications of Overture, showcasing its versatility and demand across various sectors.

With a robust team of about 227 individuals drawn from premier aerospace organizations such as SpaceX, Boeing, and NASA, Boom is seeking top talent in engineering, design, and business to help realize its ambitious vision. The company has established strategic partnerships with entities like Collins Aerospace and Safran, among others, to bring Overture to market.

Boom is also making strides beyond aircraft; they’re constructing the first American supersonic airliner factory, known as the Superfactory, in Greensboro, North Carolina. This facility will be central to Boom's mission to create a sustainable and efficient manufacturing process for supersonic aircraft.

In summary, Boom isn't just dreaming about the future of air travel—they're actively building it. They're focused not only on speed but also on sustainability, aiming to return supersonic travel to the mainstream while respecting our environmental responsibilities. If you're intrigued by the cutting-edge developments in transportation and aerospace, check out Boom Supersonic's website for the latest updates and opportunities.
